text:
It won't hurt your SEO, but why not let it help your SEO and your target audience? These webinars are usually full of great info, but in its current form, Google can't unlock that. Use a transcript service to create a rough transcript and then edit yourself, or hire someone. If you plan out the webinar well, it can easily net you three great blog posts. It will help your readers, it will also help you drive sign-ups for webinars if the content is good, and it can help you land a lot more traffic.

Just as a p.s., there really is no such thing as an SEO score. There's not many things out there in the world that can totally tank your website overnight (there's a few though). Sometimes things just make sense from a business perspective, while they don't 100% make sense from an SEO perspective. If it doesn't hurt your organic rankings, it generally makes sense just to go ahead :slightly_smiling_face:

If you wanted to leverage these to help drive SEO traffic, you could write the summary as planned, embed the video, and then provide a transcript of the event to try and pick up some long tail traffic.

Some services I’m aware (but haven’t tried)
• <https://otter.ai/|Otter>
• <https://aws.amazon.com/transcribe/|Amazon>
• <https://www.temi.com/|Temi>

text:
I've really only seen this kinda of initiative fall flat—org wants employees to be gung-ho about content and get some boost on public social media channels from a pile of excited employees... and only like 2-3 people every reliably "engage."

My intuition on why it fails: these initiatives are not treated like the marketing campaign they should be. The architects assume that internal resources are sitting around just waiting for the opportunity to participate (build it and they will come).

Two big things are invariably skipped:

1. target audience research. Just like any campaign, learn about the audience of internal people you're hoping to jazz up. What do they WANT to be seen sharing, what do they actually like, etc. Their "sense of duty" to the org probably doesn't go as deep as leadership assumes, unless your culture is :fire: 
2. Read everyone in on strategy—WHY does sharing/engaging align with both their professional and personal goals? (And if it doesn't, it's because a) the overarching campaign has no strategy and/or b), you skipped step 1
If I know what the strategy is, and it's aligned to me, AND the content going out is stuff I enjoy... well then... I'll get engaged.

text:
Hi everyone! Question about point of view. Are there any strong opinions/recommendations for using 1st person or 3rd person? Is there any harm in them being used interchangeably on a company blog? I feel like it just might depend (on brand, goals etc), but curious to see what others have to say.

(I should probably note that I’m in healthcare, not tech/saas. But we want to use our blog to help build brand awareness for the practice, and clinicians themselves will be contributing.)

elements.text:
Hi everyone! Question about point of view. Are there any strong opinions/recommendations for using 1st person or 3rd person? Is there any harm in them being used interchangeably on a company blog? I feel like it just might depend (on brand, goals etc), but curious to see what others have to say.

(I should probably note that I’m in healthcare, not tech/saas. But we want to use our blog to help build brand awareness for the practice, and clinicians themselves will be contributing.)

text: I find third person to be pretty awkward. Assuming a human being wrote the blog and it’s attributed to them under their byline, first person is a much more human approach.

elements.text: I find third person to be pretty awkward. Assuming a human being wrote the blog and it’s attributed to them under their byline, first person is a much more human approach.

text: I also use Notion and would be happy to show you my process. :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
It really depends on the content.

A case study, for example, can read too arrogant or self-serving if it's referring to the brand as an individual using "I" and "we" while referring to the customer and their brand by name. So my preference is to use 3rd person in this case.

In nearly every other case, unless it's got a byline from Tarzan of The Rock, 3rd person sounds robotic. At the same time, however, overuse of 1st person pronouns starts to sound like you're talking to yourself and forgotten there's another living, breathing human being consuming the content. It's for this reason I lean heavily towards use of 2nd person to directly address the audience.

elements.text:
It really depends on the content.

A case study, for example, can read too arrogant or self-serving if it's referring to the brand as an individual using "I" and "we" while referring to the customer and their brand by name. So my preference is to use 3rd person in this case.

In nearly every other case, unless it's got a byline from Tarzan of The Rock, 3rd person sounds robotic. At the same time, however, overuse of 1st person pronouns starts to sound like you're talking to yourself and forgotten there's another living, breathing human being consuming the content. It's for this reason I lean heavily towards use of 2nd person to directly address the audience.

text: Hey Superpath, I’m new here. I run <http://flow.club|Flow Club>, and I’d like to start highlighting some of the amazing members of our community, and thinking about the most effective way to do so. My goal is to start establishing a brand for our fledging company through highlighting the great people who make Flow Club part of their daily ritual, and build an audience through them. I looked around for some inspiration, and my favorite is <https://blog.doist.com/how-khoi-vinh-gets-things-done/|this one from Todoist> highlighting the Principal Designer at Adobe. I like it because it makes the interview subject look and sound really good and therefore more likely to be shared, but I’m curious if y’all have any critiques or improvements you’d make on this Todoist blog post, especially given how much content is already out there on the topic of productivity. I think my primary distribution channel for the content will be Twitter. Any thoughts welcome.
